analysis: The letter serves as a narrative bridge, shifting the novel from drama to reflection and re-evaluation.
Darcy's defense regarding Bingley and Jane reveals his analytical (though perhaps clinical) approach to social interactions.
His admission of concealing Jane's presence in London shows a rare moment of self-criticism ('Perhaps this concealment... was beneath me').
The detailed history of Wickham exposes the latter as a predatory opportunist, completely overturning Elizabeth's earlier perception.
The revelation about Georgiana Darcy is the most sensitive part of the letter, entrusted to Elizabeth as a sign of deep, if pained, respect.
Darcy's critique of the Bennet family's 'want of propriety' is harsh but, as the reader knows, largely accurate from an external perspective.
The shift in Darcy's tone—from the arrogance of the proposal to the formal, 'just' demand of the letter—indicates his growth and desire for integrity.

quotes.quote: I write without any intention of paining you... but I demand it of your justice.
quotes.explanation: Darcy sets the stage for a defense based on facts rather than emotion.

quotes.quote: I believed it on impartial conviction, as truly as I wished it in reason.
quotes.explanation: Darcy defends his belief that Jane was indifferent to Bingley.

quotes.quote: The total want of propriety so frequently... betrayed by herself, by your three younger sisters, and occasionally even by your father.
quotes.explanation: A brutal but honest assessment of the Bennet family's social failings.

quotes.quote: His life was a life of idleness and dissipation.
quotes.explanation: Darcy summarizes Wickham's character after receiving his payout.

quotes.quote: She was persuaded to believe herself in love and to consent to an elopement.
quotes.explanation: The shocking reveal of Wickham's attempt to ruin Darcy's sister.

quotes.quote: His chief object was unquestionably my sister's fortune... but... the hope of revenging himself on me was a strong inducement.
I was not then master enough of myself to know what could or ought to be revealed.
quotes.explanation: An apology for his behavior during the proposal, explaining his initial silence on these matters.
